Description: Weight in yellowish white stone, maybe alabaster or calcite, almost cylindrical with flat base and convex top; dome type without sharp edge; standard of weight difficult to define.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dome-shaped weights are very close to the cupcake-shaped ones; they just do not show a sharp edge, or strong carination. Such type is one of the most common weights found in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, Pl. XXIII, “domed” type), and elsewhere in Egypt (Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 3, fig. 13). Already present in the Old Kingdom, this type is particularly common on Late Period sites in the Delta (Cour-Marty 1990, 25-26, fig. 26). Dome-shaped weights are more often associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples. This specimen however is linked to another standard (around 6.4 g) which is difficult to define. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989. Les poids dans l’Égypte ancienne, Vols. 1-3 [unpublished thesis, microform], Paris. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1990, 'Les poids égyptiens, de précieux jalons archéologiques', Cahier de Recherches de l'Institut de Papyrologie et d'Egyptologie de Lille 12, 17-55. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 69-87, Pl. XXI-XXIV. Petrie, W. M. F. 1926, Ancient Weights and Measures Illustrated by the Egyptian Collection in University College, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (VA.609)
